marketNews.title: Trump Says Trade with China Will Be Fine After Threatening Additional Tariff
marketNews.content: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Sunday (12 October) that trade relations between the United States and China “will be fine.” This statement reverses his comment on Friday (10 October), when he threatened to impose an additional tariff of 100 percentage points on goods originating from China and to control all exports of important U.S. software to China starting 1 November 2025. Trump explained that the threat was based on China’s decision to tighten export restrictions on rare-earth minerals effective 1 December 2025, which also includes equipment used for mining and refining those minerals. China produces 90 % of the world’s processed rare-earths and rare-earth magnets, which are used in electric vehicles and military radars. Reuters reported that the upcoming Chinese export restrictions will require exporters to obtain a licence before exporting products containing more than 0.1 % Chinese-origin rare earths or those produced with Chinese technology. Licences will be granted to qualifying parties, though the exact criteria have not been disclosed. China will also reject export licence applications for rare-earth minerals related to the defence sector and will scrutinise applications linked to advanced semiconductors and certain artificial-intelligence applications. In response, the Chinese government urged both sides to resume negotiations, while stating it is ready to take retaliatory measures if the United States does not withdraw its policy. Currently, the U.S. tariff on Chinese products stands at 30 % and China’s tariff on U.S. goods is 10 %. The U.S. equity markets corrected sharply on Friday (10 October) with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq falling 2.7 % and 3.6 % respectively, but S&P 500 and Nasdaq futures rose about 1 % on Monday (13 October) after Trump’s softened comments over the weekend. The key takeaway is that, based on previous tariff escalations, the announced tariff threat may be a negotiating tactic as the temporary tariff-delay deadline is set to expire in mid-November 2025. Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are scheduled to meet at the APEC Summit in South Korea on 31 October–1 November 2025. Although Trump said on Friday he did not see a need to meet Xi, he later clarified that the meeting has not been cancelled.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Weighs Transforming Bali into a Regional Financial Hub
marketNews.content: The Indonesian government is planning to develop a financial hub in Bali to attract international banks, asset managers and private-equity firms. The plan aims to model the area after India’s Gujarat International Finance Tec-City (GIFT) and the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC). The hub will offer tax incentives, regulatory relaxations and streamlined bureaucracy. The policy framework is being drafted by the Ministry of Finance and the National Economic Council, with a parliamentary discussion slated for the end of 2025. National Economic Council spokesperson Jodi Mahardi confirmed the plan to Kontan.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Deputy Governor Optimistic on Credit Growth
marketNews.content: Deputy Governor of Bank Indonesia, Juda Agung, told Kontan on Friday (10 October) that the central bank is optimistic that bank credit growth can meet the target of +8-11 % year-on-year (versus +7.56 % in August 2025) because banks usually boost performance in Q4. Earlier, the Ministry of Finance also expressed optimism that credit growth could accelerate to +10 % YoY, supported by the disbursement of liquidity injections to state-owned banks (Himbara).

marketNews.title: Indonesian Lawmakers’ Session Allowance Raised to 702 Million Rupiah
marketNews.content: Indonesia’s House of Representatives members will see their per-session allowance increase from 400 million rupiah to 702 million rupiah per session. Reuters reported that members usually take about five sessions per year. Deputy Speaker Sufmi Dasco Ahmad said the increase takes effect on 3 October 2025 and was approved by the Ministry of Finance in May 2025. The government had previously withdrawn several perks for legislators to curb nationwide protests in late August 2025.

marketNews.title: SMKM Announces Sale of Up to 35.91 % of Shares to Lim Shrimp Org
marketNews.content: SMKM announced that its controlling shareholder, PT Vina Nauli Jordania, has signed an agreement to sell up to 35.91 % of SMKM shares to Lim Shrimp Org Pte. Ltd., a reduction from the previously announced up-to-44.98 % sale. The transaction value was not disclosed. After completion, Lim Shrimp Org will become the new controlling shareholder and will conduct a mandatory tender offer.

marketNews.title: PIPA Completes 43.78 % Share Acquisition by Morris Capital
marketNews.content: Multi Makmur Lemindo (PIPA) announced that PT Morris Capital Indonesia on Friday (10 October) completed the acquisition of 43.78 % of PIPA shares at an average price of 10.6 rupiah per share, amounting to roughly 15.9 billion rupiah. Previously, PIPA had announced that Morris Capital would acquire 57.37 % of the company.

marketNews.title: Bali Financial Hub Plan
marketNews.content: A Bloomberg report said the Indonesian government plans to create a financial hub in Bali to attract international banks, asset managers and private-equity firms, modelling the zone after India’s GIFT City and the UAE’s DIFC. The hub will provide tax incentives, regulatory flexibility and streamlined bureaucracy, with a legal framework possibly based on Singapore’s system. The policy draft is being prepared by the Ministry of Finance and the National Economic Council, with a parliamentary discussion expected at the end of 2025. National Economic Council spokesperson Jodi Mahardi confirmed the plan to Kontan.

tickerNews.title: BUMI Targets Gold Production from June 2026
tickerNews.content: Advisor to Bumi Resources, Christopher Fong, said Wolfram Limited will start gold production in June 2026, targeting roughly 75,000–100,000 troy ounces of gold per year within the first twelve months of operation. In a separate information disclosure, Chengdong Investment Corporation sold about 3.7 billion BUMI shares at an average price of roughly 124 rupiah per share, amounting to about 459 billion rupiah for the June-October 2025 period. After the transaction, Chengdong’s stake fell from 9.99 % to 8.99 %.

tickerNews.title: Investcorp Drops Planned Acquisition of Campina Ice Cream
tickerNews.content: DealStreetAsia reported that Bahrain-based investment manager Investcorp abandoned its planned acquisition of Campina Ice Cream Industry. DealStreetAsia earlier reported in June 2024 that Investcorp intended to buy a majority stake in CAMP from shareholder Sabana Prawirawidjaja, who held 83.94 % of CAMP. After the deal fell through, DealStreetAsia said CAMP’s shareholders are in talks with other potential buyers, including Sriwijaya Capital (backed by the Barito, Indika and Sinar Mas groups). Both CAMP and Investcorp declined to comment, and Sriwijaya Capital has not responded.

tickerNews.title: CUAN’s Subsidiary to Acquire 90 % of GDI for 680 MW Power Project
tickerNews.content: Petrindo Jaya Kreasi, through its subsidiary PT Volta Daya Energi Indonesia, announced the signing of an agreement to acquire 90 % of PT Guna Darma Integra (GDI). GDI will develop a 680 MW power plant in the integrated Feni Haltim Industrial Park in North Maluku. The project is valued at about US$600 million (≈10 trillion rupiah) with a construction timeline of 24 months.

tickerNews.title: SOSS Announces Merger with PT Alsok Bass Indonesia Security Services
tickerNews.content: Shield On Service announced a merger with its current controlling shareholder, PT Alsok Bass Indonesia Security Services (AB). After the merger, SOSS will be the surviving entity. The agreed exchange ratio is 1 AB share for 1.979 shares of the combined company. Pro-forma figures show SOSS’s net revenue would rise 14 % to 1.1 trillion rupiah, while net profit would turn into a loss of 17 billion rupiah. The merger will be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders’ meeting on 17 December 2025 and is targeted to close on 1 April 2026.

tickerNews.title: Tropical Coastland Removed from National Strategic Projects List
tickerNews.content: The Tropical Coastland project was removed from Indonesia’s National Strategic Projects list (PSN) under Minister of Coordinating Ministry of Economic Affairs Regulation No. 16 /2025. The project had previously been listed in the tourism sector under Regulation No. 12 /2024. Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua’s company secretary, Christy Grassela, told Kontan that the Tropical Coastland project is not part of PANI’s work. She also told Bisnis that the entire project lies within a protected forest area under the Ministry of Forestry and the Ministry of Environment, overseen by Perhutani. The removal from the PSN list is a government decision.
